item.title: Week 21: Live Scoring
item.description: Not a significantly productive week last week compared with previous ones, but aside from a few modular patch attempts, I participated in a live scoring Ninjam session with my usual group last weekend. We scored Luis Bu√±uel and Salvador Dali’s Un Chien Andalou (An Andalusian Dog), a surrealist short film from 1929. I prepared my modular patch for this scoring work a few hours before the actual jam. I was going for some weird, dissonant atmospheric sounds that is very different from the sounds I usually aim for.

item.title: Week 20: Coding
item.description: Back to coding this last week, where I wrote Python code for a Ninjam/Slack chat bot: ninjam-slack-bot on github Monitors a Ninjam server and sends notifications to a Slack channel everytime someone logs in. Also reports the count and list of currently logged in users. I used Errbot as the chat framework. It’s also my first project with Python 3! I got to revisit the use of the threading library, and learned several new things along the way, the most useful of which is Queue() - indispensable as it provided a very convenient means for the Ninjam-side and Slack-side processes to send messages to each other.

item.title: Week 19: DIY, Jams
item.description: Last week, I started and completed building the Temps Utile. It was a quick and pleasant build - my second one involving surface-mount components, which I now enjoy soldering! To think that I was terrified of it a few months ago. Some more photos: Starting a new project. A post shared by joon (@pirxthepilot) on May 7, 2017 at 5:08am PDT Think I'm getting the hang of soldering surface mount components.

item.title: Week 18: Track, Modular Jams
item.description: First, I started working on the actual track for “Puzzle Girl” - the song I was patching the modular for the past couple of weeks. It’s far from finished, but I managed to record a lot, and layout a rough arrangement for the first half of the song. I think I’ll leave it at that state and just come back to it after a few weeks. I also recorded a new version of my modular jam from last week.

item.title: Week 17: Modular Jam
item.description: Recorded a live jam of the patch I was working on from 2 weeks back. The main synth loops and bass are from the Aalto softsynth, and the rest are modular. This set is a combination of hardware and loops in Ableton, so I had the idea of hooking up my trusty old Akai LPD8 so I can mute/unmute tracks. A lot of processing is also done in Ableton - some reverb, lots of compression.

I meant record a tune out of it, but just did not have the time to complete one. Here’s an attempt for an arpeggiated synth bit based on the Stranger Things theme: And another, testing sampling capabilities: Live coding has opened up a lot of new avenues for me to explore.

item.title: Week 15: Modular Patch
item.description: Patch cabled out A post shared by joon (@pirxthepilot) on Apr 16, 2017 at 3:55pm PDT Not much to show except a short video of the patch I’ve been working on for the past week. It’s for a tune that I started more than two years ago, and now hope to finish with the help of the modular. It’s also the most dense patch I’ve made so far - so dense that all the VCA and attenuverted/offset channels have been used up!

item.title: Week 14: Website Development
item.description: After two long weeks, the production-ready modulogeek.com website is complete! This was created with Hugo and with the Creative theme. And a very big thanks to Google Chrome’s developer tools: it is quite a godsend. My work would have been magnitudes harder if not for this nifty invention! The site is also hosted using what I call “future tech” (cos I am old and this new way of hosting is novel to me).

item.title: Week 13: Website Development
item.description: Spent the entire last week (and this week as well, so far) making a totally new modulogeek.com website. As with this blog, I am making it with Hugo, and basing it on the Creative Theme. There isn’t much in the way of media or links to show, as the site is still in progress, and I haven’t put it online yet. Perhaps this week.. Making the new site has been more challenging than making this blog, which was mostly a straightforward theme with minimal customizations.

item.title: Week 12: DIY Eurorack, This Blog!
item.description: Last week, I started on and completed another DIY project: the Music Thing Chord Organ. It was a really nice, laid back, relaxing build - yeah, that’s right, I’ve come to a point where I find soldering stuff (the easy ones, at least) strangely comforting. I got this kit from Thonk. I also like this shop because it has a good assortment of modular DIY parts. In fact, the jacks and knobs on my previous Ornament & Crime build were from Thonk.

item.description: Against wise advice, I went ahead and purchased PCB, panels and components for the DIY module Ornament and Crime¬†(http://ornament-and-cri.me).
